Award.AwardTitle: Coordinating Multiple Decision Makers in a Service Environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop methods for controlling stochastic dynamic systems that are populated with multiple interacting agents endowed with private information, different performance objectives and different risk attitudes. The research will develop mechanisms based on revenue sharing/transfer price contracts as a way to modify agent incentives and to induce decentralized decisions that are also centrally optimal. Methods for computing both optimal as well as suboptimal revenue sharing contracts will be developed using ideas from approximate dynamic programming. Applications to multi-agent systems of interest to operations research and management science including the coordination of airline alliances, multi-agent risk management, and multi-agent service systems will be studied.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a greater understanding of the mechanisms that can be used to coordinate interacting decentralized agents in stochastic dynamic systems. It will also lead to the development of efficient methods for computing optimal and/or suboptimal revenue sharing contracts that are used to coordinate these decision makers. These results will provide guidelines for organizing and managing complex systems that are populated with multiple agents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was the study the problem of decentralized control of stochastic service and financial systems. The motivation for this research is that many such systems are populated by multiple agents with different information/observations and their own objectives, and the observation that uncoordinated decentralized control can lead to inefficient system performance due to the mis-alignment of agent level incentives to those of the centralied system. On the other hand, centralized control is often impossible due to the size and complexity of the systems. The goal of the project was to study transfer contracts as a coordination mechanism for stochastic dynamic resource allocation problems.

With regard to intellectual merit, the outcomes of the project are as follows:

1. We showed how transfer contracts can be used to coordinate the actions of decentralized agents in certain stochastic dynamic resource allocation problems including multi-agent queueing systems, multi-agent financial portfolio choice and risk management problems, and general stochastic dynamic resource allocation problems. 

2. In the case of multi-agent queueing systems, we provided a characterization of the optimal contract and showed that centralized optimality can be achieved in the decentralized system under these contracts. We also showed that the contracts have certain robustness properties to model mis-specification by decentralized agents. In particular, it is possible to achieve centralized optimality, even if every agent mis-specifies the dynamics of other agents in his/her local model. Finally, we developed a provably convergent iterative algorithm for computing the optimal contract.

3. In the case of multi-agent portfolio choice and risk management problems, we showed how swap contracts can be used to coordinate multiple decision makers such that they choose, as a collection, the optimal holdings of a centralized decision maker, and an iterative algorithm for computing these contracts that is provably convergent. One distinctive feature of this result is that local agents are not required to have knowledge of the models/information of other agents. From a higher level, one significant feature of this research is that our swap contracts are able to coordinate the system, even though standard "separability" conditions commonly required in decentralization problems are not satisfied. 

Overall, the research has the potential to change the way in multi-agent service and financial systems are managed. In particular, it proposes a mechanism for coordinating these systems and establishes favorable properties of this approach as well as a method for implementing it.

The broader impact of this research is in graduate student training. Two PhD students graduated with research on this topic, and were given the opportunity to present their research at international conferences.
